results.title: Tensions Mount As Trump Administration Threatens Federal Crackdown in Chicago
results.abstract: In a social media post, President Trump said Chicago was “about to find out why it’s called the Department of WAR.” Illinois officials condemned the message.
results.byline: By Hamed Aleaziz and Julie Bosman

multimedia.caption: Metal barricades were placed around the federal courthouse on Thursday night in the heart of Chicago’s downtown.
multimedia.copyright: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times

results.title: Man Is Identified 52 Years After He Vanished, Bringing ‘Rest’ to His Sisters
results.abstract: Eric Singer left his Ohio home on his bicycle, never to be seen again. With the help of advances in DNA research, he was finally found.

multimedia.caption: Eric Singer was 22 when he was last seen alive in Cleveland in 1973.
Eric Singer was 22 when he was last seen alive in Cleveland in 1973.
Eric Singer was 22 when he was last seen alive in Cleveland in 1973.

results.title: Justice Breyer Defends Judge Accused of Defying Supreme Court Order
results.abstract: The justice’s comments reflected tensions within the judiciary, as trial judges struggle to interpret the Supreme Court’s often cryptic emergency orders.

multimedia.caption: Former Justice Stephen Breyer in 2021.
Former Justice Stephen Breyer in 2021.
Former Justice Stephen Breyer in 2021.

results.title: President of Peace, Department of War. A New Name Sends Mixed Signals.
results.abstract: President Trump’s renaming of the Defense Department comes amid his campaign for a Nobel Peace Prize. On Saturday, he wrote on social media that Chicago was “about to find out why it’s called the Department of WAR.”
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: President Trump signed an executive order on Friday to change the name of the Defense Department to the Department of War. Without congressional approval, the new name will be only ceremonial.
President Trump signed an executive order on Friday to change the name of the Defense Department to the Department of War. Without congressional approval, the new name will be only ceremonial.

results.title: Lottery Winners Share Hard Lessons Ahead of $1.8 Billion Powerball Drawing
results.abstract: Past jackpot winners recall fortunes found, mistakes made and advice for those holding a lucky ticket.

multimedia.caption: Some last lottery winners have turned over their fortune to a financial adviser to manage. Others have seen their money fritter away on expensive purchases.

results.title: ICE Has Begun Immigration Crackdown in Massachusetts
results.abstract: The operation includes Boston, whose mayor has drawn the administration’s ire for speaking out against the growing scale of its immigration actions.

multimedia.caption: A homeland security officer observed a news briefing by Mayor Michelle Wu in Boston last month, after Attorney General Pam Bondi demanded that Boston lift its sanctuary city policies.
A homeland security officer observed a news briefing by Mayor Michelle Wu in Boston last month, after Attorney General Pam Bondi demanded that Boston lift its sanctuary city policies.

results.title: Grand Juries in D.C. Reject Wave of Charges Under Trump’s Crackdown
results.abstract: The persistent rejections suggest that the grand jurors may have had enough of prosecutors seeking harsh charges in a highly politicized environment.

multimedia.caption: Grand jurors have refused in at least seven recent cases to indict their fellow residents who became entangled in the president’s show of force.

results.title: Settlement Talks Stall Between Harvard and the Trump Administration
results.abstract: One major reason is said to be an emerging divide within the administration over whether the current framework is too favorable to Harvard.
results.byline: By Michael C. Bender, Michael S. Schmidt and Alan Blinder

multimedia.caption: The Trump administration has opened more than a dozen federal investigations into Harvard over a variety of targets, from the university’s admissions policies to its patent paperwork.
multimedia.copyright: Sophie Park for The New York Times

results.title: Many Cities Say Yes to Federal Police Help, but No to ‘Occupation’
results.abstract: Some mayors and police chiefs said they would welcome more traditional law enforcement cooperation with federal agents, but see the National Guard as a step too far.

results.title: At George Mason University, Trump Has Found an Unbending Adversary
results.abstract: Gregory Washington, George Mason’s first Black president, runs a university that prizes diversity. That has made him a target of the Trump administration.

multimedia.caption: The Trump administration demanded that Gregory Washington, president of George Mason University, personally apologize for supporting diversity programs. He said no.
multimedia.copyright: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times

results.title: What Has the Trump Administration Gotten From Law Firms and Universities?
results.abstract: A recent ruling against the Trump administration’s federal funding cuts was a temporary win for Harvard. But a dozen other institutions already struck deals with the government involving millions of dollars in payments and commitments to prioritize causes championed by the president.

results.title: Trump Says U.S. Military Has ‘Never Fought to Win’ Since World War II
results.abstract: As he signed an order recognizing the Defense Department as the “Department of War,” President Trump said that the country “could have won every war, but we really chose to be very politically correct.”
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: “The Department of War sends a signal,” President Trump said on Friday. The change, he added, was a “much more appropriate name, especially in light of where the world is right now.”
“The Department of War sends a signal,” President Trump said on Friday. The change, he added, was a “much more appropriate name, especially in light of where the world is right now.”

results.title: Will Trump Have to Run From the Economy?
results.abstract: It’s the issue voters cared most about in 2024, and there are signs of trouble.

multimedia.caption: A Gallup poll found that President Trump’s approval rating on the economy fell to 37 percent in August, compared with 42 percent in February.
A Gallup poll found that President Trump’s approval rating on the economy fell to 37 percent in August, compared with 42 percent in February.

results.title: Off-Duty Pilot Who Tried to Shut Off Engines Expresses Regret in Court
results.abstract: The former Alaska Airlines pilot had consumed psychedelic mushrooms two days before the flight. Judges approved plea agreements in his case on Friday.

multimedia.caption: Joseph D. Emerson, an off-duty Alaska Airlines pilot, was sitting in an extra seat in the cockpit during a flight on Oct. 22, 2023, when he tried to cut fuel to the engines, the authorities said.

results.title: Trump Didn’t Notify Congress About a High-Stakes SEALs Mission. That Could Be an Issue.
results.abstract: The Trump administration failed to tell lawmakers about a 2019 SEAL Team 6 incursion into North Korean territory that went awry.

results.title: How Trump’s Blunt-Force Diplomacy Is Pushing His Rivals Together
results.abstract: Some of President Trump’s pressure tactics appear to have backfired, sending would-be allies into the embrace of China.
results.byline: By Luke Broadwater and David E. Sanger

multimedia.caption: “Looks like we’ve lost India and Russia to deepest, darkest, China,” Mr. Trump wrote on Truth Social on Friday morning, as he posted a photo of the three nations’ leaders meeting in China.

results.title: New Summer Camp Safety Laws Follow Texas’ Tragic Floods
results.abstract: The families of “Heaven’s 27,” the children and counselors lost at Camp Mystic, pressed the Legislature to toughen flood rules over the objections of some Hill Country camp operators.

multimedia.caption: Gov. Greg Abbott discussing the new law, which includes a requirement for youth camps to move existing cabins away from dangerous floodplains.

results.title: Second Weak Jobs Report Undercuts Trump’s Claims of a Booming Economy
results.abstract: After a bad employment report in August, President Trump fired the official in charge of the numbers. This month’s data was just as disappointing.
results.byline: By Tony Romm and Ben Casselman

multimedia.caption: The economy added only 22,000 jobs in August. President Trump’s high tariffs and mass deportations appear to have created noticeable pressure on employers.
multimedia.copyright: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times

results.title: Leaders of African Separatist Movement Indicted in Minnesota
results.abstract: Insurgents seeking to form a new nation for English speakers in Cameroon were led by men living in Minnesota, federal prosecutors said on Friday.

multimedia.caption: Joseph H. Thompson, the acting U.S. attorney in Minnesota, at a news conference late last month. “Minnesota is not a launchpad for overseas violence,” he said in a statement on Friday about the indictment.

results.abstract: Two Democrats on the House China committee noted the use of A.I. by Chinese companies as a weapon in information warfare.

results.title: Chicago Braces for Trump’s Immigration Crackdown
results.abstract: Protesters held demonstrations and city leaders spoke against the prospect of a surge of federal agents.
